briefTitle: Efficacy and Safety of Sirolimus in LAM
officialTitle: Multicenter International Lymphangioleiomyomatosis Efficacy and Safety of Sirolimus Trial
summary: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a rare lung disease of women that is caused by genetic mutations. It results in the uncontrolled growth of an unusual type of smooth muscle cell in the lung. These cells invade lung tissue, including the airways, blood vessels, and lymph vessels, and restrict the flow of air, blood, and lymph, respectively. Respiratory failure, lung collapse (pneumothorax), and pleural effusions (chylothorax) are hallmarks of the disease. This study will evaluate the safety and effectiveness of sirolimus, an inhibitor of the mTOR pathway, in stabilizing or improving lung function in people with LAM.

primaryOutcome.measure: Changes in Forced Expiratory Volume in One-second (FEV1) Slope in Milliliters Per Month

commonTop: "Respiratory, thoracic and mediastinal disorders - Other, specify"
